column2: Matvey was already holding up the shirt like a horse's collar, and, blowing off some invisible speck, he slipped it with obvious pleasure over the well-groomed body of his master.
column3: Matvey was already holding up the shirt like a horse's collar, and, blowing off some invisible speck, he slipped it with obvious pleasure over the well groomed body of his master.

column2: Chapter 3
column3: Chapter three

column2: When he was dressed, Stepan Arkadyevitch sprinkled some scent on himself, pulled down his shirt-cuffs, distributed into his pockets his cigarettes, pocketbook, matches, and watch with its double chain and seals, and shaking out his handkerchief, feeling himself clean, fragrant, healthy, and physically at ease, in spite of his unhappiness, he walked with a slight swing on each leg into the dining-room, where coffee was already waiting for him, and beside the coffee, letters and papers from the office.
column3: When he was dressed, Stepan Arkadyevitch sprinkled some scent on himself, pulled down his shirt cuffs, distributed into his pockets his cigarettes, pocketbook, matches, and watch with its double chain and seals, and shaking out his handkerchief, feeling himself clean, fragrant, healthy, and physically at ease, in spite of his unhappiness, he walked with a slight swing on each leg into the dining room, where coffee was already waiting for him, and beside the coffee, letters and papers from the office.

column2: He read the letters.
column3: He read the letters.

column2: One was very unpleasant, from a merchant who was buying a forest on his wife's property.
column3: One was very unpleasant, from a merchant who was buying a forest on his wife's property.

column2: To sell this forest was absolutely essential; but at present, until he was reconciled with his wife, the subject could not be discussed.
column3: To sell this forest was absolutely essential; but at present, until he was reconciled with his wife, the subject could not be discussed.

column2: The most unpleasant thing of all was that his pecuniary interests should in this way enter into the question of his reconciliation with his wife.
column3: The most unpleasant thing of all was that his pecuniary interests should in this way enter into the question of his reconciliation with his wife.

column2: And the idea that he might be led on by his interests, that he might seek a reconciliation with his wife on account of the sale of the forest--that idea hurt him.
column3: And the idea that he might be led on by his interests, that he might seek a reconciliation with his wife on account of the sale of the forest-that idea hurt him.

column2: When he had finished his letters, Stepan Arkadyevitch moved the office-papers close to him, rapidly looked through two pieces of business, made a few notes with a big pencil, and pushing away the papers, turned to his coffee.
column3: When he had finished his letters, Stepan Arkadyevitch moved the office papers close to him, rapidly looked through two pieces of business, made a few notes with a big pencil, and pushing away the papers, turned to his coffee.

column2: As he sipped his coffee, he opened a still damp morning paper, and began reading it.
column3: As he sipped his coffee, he opened a still damp morning paper, and began reading it.

column2: Stepan Arkadyevitch took in and read a liberal paper, not an extreme one, but one advocating the views held by the majority.
column3: Stepan Arkadyevitch took in and read a liberal paper, not an extreme one, but one advocating the views held by the majority.

column2: And in spite of the fact that science, art, and politics had no special interest for him, he firmly held those views on all these subjects which were held by the majority and by his paper, and he only changed them when the majority changed them--or, more strictly speaking, he did not change them, but they imperceptibly changed of themselves within him.
column3: And in spite of the fact that science, art, and politics had no special interest for him, he firmly held those views on all these subjects which were held by the majority and by his paper, and he only changed them when the majority changed them-or, more strictly speaking, he did not change them, but they imperceptibly changed of themselves within him.

column2: Stepan Arkadyevitch had not chosen his political opinions or his views; these political opinions and views had come to him of themselves, just as he did not choose the shapes of his hat and coat, but simply took those that were being worn.
column3: Stepan Arkadyevitch had not chosen his political opinions or his views; these political opinions and views had come to him of themselves, just as he did not choose the shapes of his hat and coat, but simply took those that were being worn.

column2: And for him, living in a certain society--owing to the need, ordinarily developed at years of discretion, for some degree of mental activity--to have views was just as indispensable as to have a hat.
column3: And for him, living in a certain society-owing to the need, ordinarily developed at years of discretion, for some degree of mental activity-to have views was just as indispensable as to have a hat.

column2: If there was a reason for his preferring liberal to conservative views, which were held also by many of his circle, it arose not from his considering liberalism more rational, but from its being in closer accordance with his manner of life.
column3: If there was a reason for his preferring liberal to conservative views, which were held also by many of his circle, it arose not from his considering liberalism more rational, but from its being in closer accordance with his manner of life.

column2: The liberal party said that in Russia everything is wrong, and certainly Stepan Arkadyevitch had many debts and was decidedly short of money.
column3: The liberal party said that in Russia everything is wrong, and certainly Stepan Arkadyevitch had many debts and was decidedly short of money.

column2: The liberal party said that marriage is an institution quite out of date, and that it needs reconstruction; and family life certainly afforded Stepan Arkadyevitch little gratification, and forced him into lying and hypocrisy, which was so repulsive to his nature.
column3: The liberal party said that marriage is an institution quite out of date, and that it needs reconstruction; and family life certainly afforded Stepan Arkadyevitch little gratification, and forced him into lying and hypocrisy, which was so repulsive to his nature.

column2: The liberal party said, or rather allowed it to be understood, that religion is only a curb to keep in check the barbarous classes of the people; and Stepan Arkadyevitch could not get through even a short service without his legs aching from standing up, and could never make out what was the object of all the terrible and high-flown language about another world when life might be so very amusing in this world.
column3: The liberal party said, or rather allowed it to be understood, that religion is only a curb to keep in check the barbarous classes of the people; and Stepan Arkadyevitch could not get through even a short service without his legs aching from standing up, and could never make out what was the object of all the terrible and high flown language about another world when life might be so very amusing in this world.

column2: And with all this, Stepan Arkadyevitch, who liked a joke, was fond of puzzling a plain man by saying that if he prided himself on his origin, he ought not to stop at Rurik and disown the first founder of his family--the monkey.
column3: And with all this, Stepan Arkadyevitch, who liked a joke, was fond of puzzling a plain man by saying that if he prided himself on his origin, he ought not to stop at Rurik and disown the first founder of his family-the monkey.

column2: And so Liberalism had become a habit of Stepan Arkadyevitch's, and he liked his newspaper, as he did his cigar after dinner, for the slight fog it diffused in his brain.
column3: And so Liberalism had become a habit of Stepan Arkadyevitch's, and he liked his newspaper, as he did his cigar after dinner, for the slight fog it diffused in his brain.

column2: He read the leading article, in which it was maintained that it was quite senseless in our day to raise an outcry that radicalism was threatening to swallow up all conservative elements, and that the government ought to take measures to crush the revolutionary hydra; that, on the contrary, "in our opinion the danger lies not in that fantastic revolutionary hydra, but in the obstinacy of traditionalism clogging progress," etc., etc.
column3: He read the leading article, in which it was maintained that it was quite senseless in our day to raise an outcry that radicalism was threatening to swallow up all conservative elements, and that the government ought to take measures to crush the revolutionary hydra; that, on the contrary, "in our opinion the danger lies not in that fantastic revolutionary hydra, but in the obstinacy of traditionalism clogging progress," etc, etc

column2: He read another article, too, a financial one, which alluded to Bentham and Mill, and dropped some innuendoes reflecting on the ministry.
column3: He read another article, too, a financial one, which alluded to Bentham and Mill, and dropped some innuendoes reflecting on the ministry.

column2: With his characteristic quickwittedness he caught the drift of each innuendo, divined whence it came, at whom and on what ground it was aimed, and that afforded him, as it always did, a certain satisfaction.
column3: With his characteristic quickwittedness he caught the drift of each innuendo, divined whence it came, at whom and on what ground it was aimed, and that afforded him, as it always did, a certain satisfaction.

column2: But today that satisfaction was embittered by Matrona Philimonovna's advice and the unsatisfactory state of the household.
column3: But today that satisfaction was embittered by Matrona Philimonovna's advice and the unsatisfactory state of the household.

column2: He read, too, that Count Beist was rumored to have left for Wiesbaden, and that one need have no more gray hair, and of the sale of a light carriage, and of a young person seeking a situation; but these items of information did not give him, as usual, a quiet, ironical gratification.
column3: He read, too, that Count Beist was rumored to have left for Wiesbaden, and that one need have no more gray hair, and of the sale of a light carriage, and of a young person seeking a situation; but these items of information did not give him, as usual, a quiet, ironical gratification.

column2: Having finished the paper, a second cup of coffee and a roll and butter, he got up, shaking the crumbs of the roll off his waistcoat; and, squaring his broad chest, he smiled joyously: not because there was anything particularly agreeable in his mind--the joyous smile was evoked by a good digestion.
column3: Having finished the paper, a second cup of coffee and a roll and butter, he got up, shaking the crumbs of the roll off his waistcoat; and, squaring his broad chest, he smiled joyously: not because there was anything particularly agreeable in his mind-the joyous smile was evoked by a good digestion.

column2: But this joyous smile at once recalled everything to him, and he grew thoughtful.
column3: But this joyous smile at once recalled everything to him, and he grew thoughtful.

column2: Two childish voices (Stepan Arkadyevitch recognized the voices of Grisha, his youngest boy, and Tanya, his eldest girl) were heard outside the door.
column3: Two childish voices (Stepan Arkadyevitch recognized the voices of Grisha, his youngest boy, and Tanya, his eldest girl) were heard outside the door.

column2: They were carrying something, and dropped it.
column3: They were carrying something, and dropped it.

column2: I told you not to sit passengers on the roof, said the little girl in English; "there, pick them up!"
column3: I told you not to sit passengers on the roof, said the little girl in English; "there, pick them up!"

column2: Everything's in confusion, thought Stepan Arkadyevitch; "there are the children running about by themselves." And going to the door, he called them.
column3: Everything's in confusion, thought Stepan Arkadyevitch; "there are the children running about by themselves." And going to the door, he called them.

column2: They threw down the box, that represented a train, and came in to their father.
column3: They threw down the box, that represented a train, and came in to their father.

column2: The little girl, her father's favorite, ran up boldly, embraced him, and hung laughingly on his neck, enjoying as she always did the smell of scent that came from his whiskers.
column3: The little girl, her father's favorite, ran up boldly, embraced him, and hung laughingly on his neck, enjoying as she always did the smell of scent that came from his whiskers.

column2: At last the little girl kissed his face, which was flushed from his stooping posture and beaming with tenderness, loosed her hands, and was about to run away again; but her father held her back.
column3: At last the little girl kissed his face, which was flushed from his stooping posture and beaming with tenderness, loosed her hands, and was about to run away again; but her father held her back.

column2: How is mamma? he asked, passing his hand over his daughter's smooth, soft little neck.
column3: How is mamma? he asked, passing his hand over his daughter's smooth, soft little neck.

column2: Good morning, he said, smiling to the boy, who had come up to greet him.
column3: Good morning, he said, smiling to the boy, who had come up to greet him.

column2: He was conscious that he loved the boy less, and always tried to be fair; but the boy felt it, and did not respond with a smile to his father's chilly smile.
column3: He was conscious that he loved the boy less, and always tried to be fair; but the boy felt it, and did not respond with a smile to his father's chilly smile.

column2: Mamma?	Mamma?
column3: true

column2: She is up," answered the girl.
column3: She is up," answered the girl.

column2: Stepan Arkadyevitch sighed.
column3: Stepan Arkadyevitch sighed.

column2: That means that she's not slept again all night, he thought.
column3: That means that she's not slept again all night, he thought.

column2: Well, is she cheerful?
column3: Well, is she cheerful?

column2: The little girl knew that there was a quarrel between her father and mother, and that her mother could not be cheerful, and that her father must be aware of this, and that he was pretending when he asked about it so lightly.
column3: The little girl knew that there was a quarrel between her father and mother, and that her mother could not be cheerful, and that her father must be aware of this, and that he was pretending when he asked about it so lightly.

column2: And she blushed for her father.
column3: And she blushed for her father.

column2: He at once perceived it, and blushed too.
column3: He at once perceived it, and blushed too.

column2: I don't know, she said.
column3: I don't know, she said.

column2: She did not say we must do our lessons, but she said we were to go for a walk with Miss Hoole to grandmamma's.
column3: She did not say we must do our lessons, but she said we were to go for a walk with Miss Hoole to grandmamma's.

column2: Well, go, Tanya, my darling.	Well, go, Tanya, my darling.
column3: true

column2: Oh, wait a minute, though," he said, still holding her and stroking her soft little hand.
column3: Oh, wait a minute, though," he said, still holding her and stroking her soft little hand.

column2: He took off the mantelpiece, where he had put it yesterday, a little box of sweets, and gave her two, picking out her favorites, a chocolate and a fondant.
column3: He took off the mantelpiece, where he had put it yesterday, a little box of sweets, and gave her two, picking out her favorites, a chocolate and a fondant.

column2: For Grisha? said the little girl, pointing to the chocolate.
column3: For Grisha? said the little girl, pointing to the chocolate.

column2: Yes, yes. And still stroking her little shoulder, he kissed her on the roots of her hair and neck, and let her go.
column3: Yes, yes. And still stroking her little shoulder, he kissed her on the roots of her hair and neck, and let her go.

column2: The carriage is ready, said Matvey; "but there's some one to see you with a petition."
column3: The carriage is ready, said Matvey; "but there's some one to see you with a petition."

column2: Been here long? asked Stepan Arkadyevitch.
column3: Been here long? asked Stepan Arkadyevitch.

column2: Half an hour.
column3: Half an hour.

column2: How many times have I told you to tell me at once?
column3: How many times have I told you to tell me at once?

column2: One must let you drink your coffee in peace, at least, said Matvey, in the affectionately gruff tone with which it was impossible to be angry.
column3: One must let you drink your coffee in peace, at least, said Matvey, in the affectionately gruff tone with which it was impossible to be angry.

column2: Well, show the person up at once, said Oblonsky, frowning with vexation.
column3: Well, show the person up at once, said Oblonsky, frowning with vexation.

column2: The petitioner, the widow of a staff captain Kalinin, came with a request impossible and unreasonable; but Stepan Arkadyevitch, as he generally did, made her sit down, heard her to the end attentively without interrupting her, and gave her detailed advice as to how and to whom to apply, and even wrote her, in his large, sprawling, good and legible hand, a confident and fluent little note to a personage who might be of use to her.
column3: The petitioner, the widow of a staff captain Kalinin, came with a request impossible and unreasonable; but Stepan Arkadyevitch, as he generally did, made her sit down, heard her to the end attentively without interrupting her, and gave her detailed advice as to how and to whom to apply, and even wrote her, in his large, sprawling, good and legible hand, a confident and fluent little note to a personage who might be of use to her.

column2: Having got rid of the staff captain's widow, Stepan Arkadyevitch took his hat and stopped to recollect whether he had forgotten anything.
column3: Having got rid of the staff captain's widow, Stepan Arkadyevitch took his hat and stopped to recollect whether he had forgotten anything.

column2: It appeared that he had forgotten nothing except what he wanted to forget--his wife.
column3: It appeared that he had forgotten nothing except what he wanted to forget-his wife.

column2: Ah, yes! He bowed his head, and his handsome face assumed a harassed expression.
column3: Ah, yes! He bowed his head, and his handsome face assumed a harassed expression.

column2: To go, or not to go! he said to himself; and an inner voice told him he must not go, that nothing could come of it but falsity; that to amend, to set right their relations was impossible, because it was impossible to make her attractive again and able to inspire love, or to make him an old man, not susceptible to love.
column3: To go, or not to go! he said to himself; and an inner voice told him he must not go, that nothing could come of it but falsity; that to amend, to set right their relations was impossible, because it was impossible to make her attractive again and able to inspire love, or to make him an old man, not susceptible to love.

column2: Except deceit and lying nothing could come of it now; and deceit and lying were opposed to his nature.
column3: Except deceit and lying nothing could come of it now; and deceit and lying were opposed to his nature.

column2: It must be some time, though: it can't go on like this, he said, trying to give himself courage.
column3: It must be some time, though: it can't go on like this, he said, trying to give himself courage.

column2: He squared his chest, took out a cigarette, took two whiffs at it, flung it into a mother-of-pearl ashtray, and with rapid steps walked through the drawing room, and opened the other door into his wife's bedroom.
column3: He squared his chest, took out a cigarette, took two whiffs at it, flung it into a mother of pearl ashtray, and with rapid steps walked through the drawing room, and opened the other door into his wife's bedroom.

column2: Chapter 4
column3: Chapter four

column2: Darya Alexandrovna, in a dressing jacket, and with her now scanty, once luxuriant and beautiful hair fastened up with hairpins on the nape of her neck, with a sunken, thin face and large, startled eyes, which looked prominent from the thinness of her face, was standing among a litter of all sorts of things scattered all over the room, before an open bureau, from which she was taking something.
column3: Darya Alexandrovna, in a dressing jacket, and with her now scanty, once luxuriant and beautiful hair fastened up with hairpins on the nape of her neck, with a sunken, thin face and large, startled eyes, which looked prominent from the thinness of her face, was standing among a litter of all sorts of things scattered all over the room, before an open bureau, from which she was taking something.

column2: Hearing her husband's steps, she stopped, looking towards the door, and trying assiduously to give her features a severe and contemptuous expression.
column3: Hearing her husband's steps, she stopped, looking towards the door, and trying assiduously to give her features a severe and contemptuous expression.

column2: She felt she was afraid of him, and afraid of the coming interview.
column3: She felt she was afraid of him, and afraid of the coming interview.

column2: She was just attempting to do what she had attempted to do ten times already in these last three days--to sort out the children's things and her own, so as to take them to her mother's--and again she could not bring herself to do this; but now again, as each time before, she kept saying to herself, "that things cannot go on like this, that she must take some step" to punish him, put him to shame, avenge on him some little part at least of the suffering he had caused her.
column3: She was just attempting to do what she had attempted to do ten times already in these last three days-to sort out the children's things and her own, so as to take them to her mother's-and again she could not bring herself to do this; but now again, as each time before, she kept saying to herself, "that things cannot go on like this, that she must take some step" to punish him, put him to shame, avenge on him some little part at least of the suffering he had caused her.

column2: She still continued to tell herself that she should leave him, but she was conscious that this was impossible; it was impossible because she could not get out of the habit of regarding him as her husband and loving him.
column3: She still continued to tell herself that she should leave him, but she was conscious that this was impossible; it was impossible because she could not get out of the habit of regarding him as her husband and loving him.

column2: Besides this, she realized that if even here in her own house she could hardly manage to look after her five children properly, they would be still worse off where she was going with them all.
column3: Besides this, she realized that if even here in her own house she could hardly manage to look after her five children properly, they would be still worse off where she was going with them all.

column2: As it was, even in the course of these three days, the youngest was unwell from being given unwholesome soup, and the others had almost gone without their dinner the day before.
column3: As it was, even in the course of these three days, the youngest was unwell from being given unwholesome soup, and the others had almost gone without their dinner the day before.

column2: She was conscious that it was impossible to go away; but, cheating herself, she went on all the same sorting out her things and pretending she was going.
column3: She was conscious that it was impossible to go away; but, cheating herself, she went on all the same sorting out her things and pretending she was going.
